newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Growth shortfall would cut NZ surplus - Peters.
newsitem.headline: Growth shortfall would cut NZ surplus - Peters.

text.p: New Zealand Treasurer Winston Peters said on Wednesday that the government's operating surplus would fall by NZ$400 million if growth was one percent lower than Treasury was forecasting.
Peters, replying to questions from parliament's finance and expenditure committee, said he did not expect this to happen.

"If that should happen, we would be looking at our level of surplus to accommodate that," Peters said. "We would have to look at all options...and not rule out any." He said the government's options would be to lower the operating surplus or to restrain expenditure.
In the Budget Policy Statement released on March 4, Treasury forecast surpluses of NZ$3.3 billion in 1997/98, $2.6 billion in 1998/99 and $3.5 billion in 1999/00.

In its December Economic and Fiscal Update, Treasury forecast an annual average economic growth rate of 2.6 percent in the year to March 1997 and 3.6 percent in the 1997/98 year, assuming no policy changes.
It said growth would fall to 3.1 percent in 1998/99 and rise again to 3.5 percent in 1999/2000.
